surface and mixed layer depth are the same, since the slab-ocean simulation does
not allow lateral transport. The annual-mean climatological Q-

ux pattern as a negative (i.e., heat
out of the mixed layer depth into the ocean) and positive (i.e., heat
atmosphere) ocean heat uptake forcing inducing a global warming and cooling.

The naming convention for the simulations is as follows: NP-Warm (North
perturbations, and NP-Warm/NA-Cool and NP-Cool/NA-Warm denoting the
ux perturbations. Simulations were also run with the
ux perturbations in each basin with modi
land topography, such that the global land surface was set to a geopotential height

ux imposed in the Northeast Paci
equivalent to the area of the Atlantic heat
. All simulations were run for 100 model years and annual
and seasonal averages were calculated for years 40
the exception of the NEP-Warm simulation, which was run for 60 model years
with mean values calculated from years 40 to 60. Reported errors are calculated as
the standard error of the mean multiplied by 1.96, which is the number of standard
deviations required to contain 95% of the area of a normal distribution. The
calculation of the standard error of the mean assumes a sample size of
pendent samples, which in our case are the individual model years. Autocorrelation
between model years, however, reduces the number of independent samples, as
This autocorrelation is corrected for by using Eq. (6) of
We calculate the global climate feedback parameter (
is the change in global average
cation factor is calculated as the ratio
of the change in global surface air temperature to the change in Arctic surface air
) (Table 1). The cloud radiative forcing at the TOA is
calculated as the difference in the net radiative
conditions. The greenhouse effect of clouds in the Arctic is calculated as the
difference in the downwelling longwave radiation at the surface between all-sky
. We calculate the surface albedo forcing related to
changes in sea-ice as the difference in upwelling shortwave radiation at the surface
in clear-sky conditions. However, the enhanced absorption of shortwave radiation
at the surface due to sea-ice retreat is in part compensated by enhanced shortwave
ection at the TOA due to changes in Arctic cloudiness. For example, the greater
increase in Arctic cloud fraction in the NP-Warm contributes to an annual-mean
negative cloud radiative effect at the top of the atmosphere (TOA) (
for the NP-Warm and NA-Warm simulations, respectively).
However, this is composed of a positive cloud radiative effect from trapped
when the maximum Arctic warming occurs
ected shortwave in the summer, during which season
the decreased albedo from sea-ice loss more than compensates for the increased
ection. Thus, the warming effect of low clouds and sea-ice retreat together
more than compensate for the reduction in incoming shortwave at the TOA due to
The net change in shortwave radiation at the surface is interpreted as the
effective shortwave absorption due to both cloud and sea-ice changes. Moisture
convergence in the Arctic is de
ned as precipitation minus the surface water
Changes in Arctic sea-ice and cloud fraction are reported as the percent change in
the area fraction relative to the control simulation. All calculations for the Arctic

perturbation in NP-Warm and NA-Warm cases is shown in Fig. 5a.
In order to diagnose where the latent energy is entering the Arctic in the NP-
Warm and NA-Warm simulations, we analyzed the longitudinal distribution of
latent energy transport across 66.6°N (Fig. 5b). We calculate this as the
longitudinally resolved latent energy component of the vertically integrated moist
integrating between atmospheric pressure at the surface (
previous equations. The moisture transport (vq) is calculated using the model
online diagnostic VQ, which outputs the multiplication of the two terms at each
model time step and includes both the mean and the eddy components of the latent
energy transport (Supplementary Figure 5). The direct Arctic heating from
atmospheric energy convergence is calculated as the total atmospheric northward
energy transport values divided by the area of the Arctic (2.089 × 10
were calculated as an average of the following 23 models relative to their average

CAM5, CNRM-CM5, CSIRO-Mk3-6-0, EC-EARTH, FIO-ESM, GFDL-CM3,

gures were generated using the PyFerret software from NOAA
